body: AS a youth in Brooklyn, he was helpless when the lords of baseball moved his beloved Dodgers to Los Angeles -- a calamity, he jokes today, that ''precipitated the decline of American civilization.'' But fresh out of Harvard University in the mid-1960's, he achieved a modest measure of influence over events by joining the civil rights crusade in the
title: Yes, You Can Do Something About the Weather

body: Three men were charged with murder yesterday in the shooting deaths of an off-duty police officer and a Queens businessman last week. The arrests, which came after one suspect was picked up on a minor drug charge, were hailed by Police Commissioner Howard Safir as an especially gratifying example of how the city's crackdown on ''quality of life''
title: 3 Charged in Killings of Officer and Businessman in Queens

body: NEW YORK Hospitals Faulted on Treatment New York State health officials leveled fines and unusually harsh criticism at Cabrini Medical Center and St. Vincent's Medical Center for deficiencies in their emergency-room treatment of the playwright Jonathan Larson in the days before his death this year. Mr. Larson, 35, who created ''Rent,'' was rushed
title: Metro Digest

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was visibly thrilled on Wednesday night when a woman stood up at a town meeting that he was holding in the Midwood section of Brooklyn and condemned the City Council for voting down his superstore plan, just as he had been doing all week. After joking that he should hire the woman, he assured skeptics in the audience that
title: How Fears in the Neighborhoods Killed the Mayor's Superstore Plan

body: During a typical evening rush hour at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, the traffic police wrestle with cars backed up for six blocks. All around them, the area is teeming with office workers heading home, parents buying groceries and teen-agers cruising. It is evidence that Downtown Brooklyn is outgrowing itself. Chronic traffic congestion has
title: For Downtown Traffic, Growing Pains May Turn Critical

body: For years, residents of western Brooklyn have dreaded the upcoming reconstruction of the Gowanus Expressway, a project that would swamp neighborhoods with traffic for at least five years. But an alternative may be emerging: replacing the crumbling elevated expressway with an underground highway. Ultimately, the most important question is whether
title: As Unpopular Gowanus Overhaul Looms, a Tunnel Plan Gains Notice

body: There were no major foul-ups like those that greeted many Brooklyn voters in the September primary, when voting machines failed to show up, but a few scattered problems were reported at New York City polling places yesterday. Board of Elections officials said that this Election Day had had no more problems than should be expected in any contest.
title: Problems Keep Some From The Polls

body: A healthy baby girl only a few hours old was found yesterday in a cardboard box outside an apartment building in Brooklyn, the police said. The infant was discovered by a child who lived in the neighborhood, said an official at Maimonides Medical Center, where the baby was taken. ''She was found by a little girl next to a trash area,'' said Pamela
title: Baby Is Found Left in a Box, Just Hours Old

body: Stephen J. Friedman, who produced ''The Last Picture Show,'' ''Slap Shot'' and ''The Big Easy,'' died on Oct. 4 at his home in Brentwood, Calif. He was 59. The cause was multiple myeloma, a form of cancer, said Ken Aguado, his nephew. Mr. Friedman was born in Brooklyn and attended Midwood High School. After graduating from the Wharton School at the
title: Stephen Friedman, Film Producer, 59

body: Marjorie Shostak, a woman from a traditional family in Flatbush whose book about a bold older woman from the !Kung San tribe in Africa's Kalahari Desert rode an early wave of women's studies and injected new life into techniques of anthropology, died on Sunday at DeKalb Medical Center in Atlanta. She was 51. The cause was breast cancer, family
title: Marjorie Shostak, 51, Author Who Wrote of Tribal Woman

body: New Jersey Cooper Rego, who is bound for Notre Dame, rushed for 448 yards and 5 touchdowns as top-ranked ST. JOSEPH-MONTVALE (3-0) survived a seesaw battle with the perennial power PARAMUS CATHOLIC (2-1), 44-29. Rego scored on runs of 6, 4 and 39 yards and on two 50-yard sprints. . . . Anthony Bogan rushed for 111 yards and 2 touchdowns as PASSAIC
title: Rego's Big Day Lifts St. Joseph-Montvale

body: Five major faiths will be in conflict today as the Giants play the Jets, the Yankees play the Red Sox, and Yom Kippur, the holiest day of the Jewish calendar, begins at sundown. How some fans observe these rituals will offer commentary on the old line that sports is America's religion and religion is America's sport. The teams involved all
title: Faith Meets The Secular SportsWorld

body: Faced with a possible death sentence if convicted under a new Federal death penalty statute, two reputed members of a Chinese gang opted yesterday for a mandatory life sentence without parole, pleading guilty to charges that they had kidnapped, tortured and killed an immigrant Chinese woman in a ransom plot. But a third man refused to accept the
title: Facing Death Penalty in Murder, Two Opt for Life

body: ON a humid morning last week, Michael D. Benjamin stood at the entrance to the subway station at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, passing out campaign material and urging riders to vote for his candidate. Some people stopped and listened. Many simply darted by, looking more than a little annoyed. After all, Mr. Benjamin was stumping for a candidate in
title: Wake Up! It's Primary Time

body: On Friday morning, the man in charge of of Public School 99 in Midwood, Brooklyn, roamed the schoolyard, coaxing, cajoling and hollering at the school's 1,000 students to file inside. What appeared to be just business as usual masked several months of heated controversy over the selection of a principal for the school and an underlying debate over
title: Parents' Veto Stalls Choice Of a Principal

body: As New York City's 660 elementary schools reopened yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said that the overcrowding at many schools would be a fact of life for tens of thousands of students and teachers for some time to come. ''I think you have to have some patience and flexibility in dealing with this,'' Mr.
title: School Overcrowding to Last, New York City Officials Say

body: Robert Reinhold, an editorial writer at The Los Angeles Times and before that a longtime reporter for The New York Times, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 54. The cause was complications of a brain tumor, said Dr. Timothy Cloughsey, a neuro-oncologist at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. Mr. Reinhold
title: Robert Reinhold, Ex-Reporter For The Times, Is Dead at 54

body: BATTERY PARK CITY Cool Sounds For Summer's End The Bronx Arts Ensemble will give a free all-Handel concert on Tuesday at Hudson River Park in Battery Park City as part of the ''Sounds of the Hudson'' celebration. The program will include -- appropriately enough -- the complete ''Water Music,'' with Kenneth Cooper conducting from the harpsichord.
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: To the Editor: Did it ever occur to Mr. Finkle that drivers who follow traffic procedures have been put upon by the pedestrian or jogger who tries to beat the red light? What if the drivers adopted the same idea -- don't stop for red lights and weave between walkers? ETHEL R. FRIEDMAN Midwood, Brooklyn
title: Dispatches From a War of Nerves

body: The government listing in the Gazetteer chart last Sunday, with an article about living in the Midwood section of Brooklyn, omitted a City Councilman who represents part of the area. He is Noach Dear, a Democrat.
title: Correction

body: After years of setbacks and with little fanfare, bulldozers began uprooting dozens of trees in a scruffy Brooklyn park last weekend to make way for a major development that will give Brooklyn its first large hotel since the 1930's and is widely considered a key to downtown renewal. The razing of the park signals the end of 13 years of struggles to
title: Land Clearing Starts for Brooklyn Hotel

body: ABOUT a decade ago, an influx of Russians that turned into a torrent began in the central Brooklyn neighborhood of Midwood, which is anchored by Brooklyn College. Their numbers have led at least one bank, a Chase branch on Avenue M, to offer the choice of the Russian language on its ATM machines. The Russians joined earlier waves of immigrants --
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Midwood;A Rich Ethnic Mix in Mid-Brooklyn

title: BATTLE AT THE BOARD OF EDUCATION: THE CHALLENGER -- Man in the News;A Knack for Compromise: William Colridge Thompson Jr.

body: Jillur Rahman has spent five years in his brick house in Midwood, Brooklyn, long enough to know every face on his block and for his 4-year-old son to know no other home. So he was devastated when he received the call from his former landlord telling him that he would have to move and that a judge would decide how soon. What do you say?" Mr. Rahman
title: Bank's Good-Neighbor Efforts Yield Some Unwanted Returns;Risky Mortgages Force Eviction of Paying Tenants

He told her how great she was, and she asked him, 'What did you think of Gerry's work?' " She was referring, of course, to her director, Gerald Gutierrez. "He seemed taken
title: THEATER;More Adult, And Stronger Than He Knew

body: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS Around the Kitchen Table: An Immigrant Community In 1870, there were seven Chinese immigrants living in Brooklyn. In 1990, according to the census, there were 68,191. This growing community is the subject of the Brooklyn Historical Society's exhibit New Neighbors: Sunset Park's Chinese Community. The society has previously looked
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Long ago, before the world turned upside down, there existed a Europe where civilized people could sip afternoon coffee, eat fine pastries and listen to music. Then came the Holocaust and lives, families and hope were ripped apart. More than half a century has passed since the liberation of the concentration camps. Many came to America to build new
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDWOOD;For Survivors, Kaffeeklatshes Open a Window to Old World

body: It was September 1991, the summer of the violence in Crown Heights. Tensions between blacks and Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn erupted after a Hasidic driver struck and killed a 7-year-old black child. In retaliation, black youths attacked and killed a Hasidic Jew. Three weeks later, in Far Rockaway, Queens, another incident sounded disturbing echoes. A
title: Keeping Peace Alive And Tensions Dormant;Diverse Far Rockaway Sees Room For Harmony as Jewish Enclave Grows

body: When Pete Pedone was a top dee-jay back in the late 70s, when the music was at its peak, he was the main-man-with-the-aqua-green-van, the disco dude who got 400 phone numbers in the single calendar year of 1979. The world belonged to him and he was unstoppable, sauve, smooth-talking and he had a steady gig mixing wax and 8-tracks for Brooklyn's
title: Saturday Night Fever: The Life

body: FOR Joseph Ehrlichster, an Orthodox Jew and a real estate investor, keeping kosher gives him just about the same gastronomic privileges as everyone else in New York. Except when it comes to sushi. Until recently, Japanese food -- sushi in particular -- has been off limits for people like Mr. Erhlichster, available only through catering services.
title: Three Restaurants Make Kosher Sushi (Hold the Shellfish)

body: A lawyer with a reputation for charitable deeds was charged yesterday with swindling victims out of nearly $14 million using bogus real estate schemes, and a Federal court complaint said that he had told another lawyer that his swindles had totaled more than $50 million. The lawyer who was charged, David Schick, is a member of a prominent Orthodox
title: U.S. Says Brooklyn Lawyer Stole Millions Using Property Schemes

body: Federal investigators are looking into accusations that a lawyer prominent in the Orthodox Jewish community in Brooklyn swindled millions of dollars from real estate investors, many if not most of whom were Orthodox Jews, law-enforcement officials said. A lawyer for David Schick, the man under investigation, acknowledged yesterday that his client
title: Lawyer Is Investigated in Real Estate Fraud

body: For a fee of $35 per semester, Donald Kramer earned a diploma from Brooklyn College. The year was 1958, and a degree in economics was his ticket from Bensonhurst to the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Gone are the days when students like Mr. Kramer, now the chief executive of a Bermuda-based insurance company, or the lawyer Alan Dershowitz or the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDWOOD;Thanking a College a Million

title: A Little Brooklyn Job With Lots of Influence

body: Knowing next to no one, Mesut Yaktubay stepped off the plane from Turkey two weeks ago and became an instant regular at Sunny Grocery, a postage-stamp-sized market on an unremarkable corner in Sunnyside, Queens. title: In the Queens Mosaic, A Turkish Inlay;Community Takes Root in Sunnyside

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: STUYVESANT SQUARE;Old Idea in New Age: Night School

body: MIDWOOD Haitian Voodoo Beat, Traditional and Modern The music of Haitian voodoo, in the traditional style and blended with contemporary jazz, will be performed at Brooklyn College Saturday night by artists who are part of the borough's Haitian population. The show will open with La Troupe Makandal, who began performing voodoo ceremonies in
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: NEW YORK CITY Fierce Winds Cause Deaths Fierce winds that whipped to more than 60 miles an hour caused at least three deaths in the metropolitan region and contributed to the collapse of at least two buildings in Brooklyn. In Midwood, Brooklyn, a sharp gust ripped a tree from its roots and sent it flying across the street, where it crushed a
title: Metro Digest

body: Fierce winds that whipped to more than 60 miles per hour caused at least three deaths in the metropolitan region yesterday along with severe damage to some homes and businesses, as gusts uprooted trees, peeled roofs away and contributed to the collapse of at least two buildings in Brooklyn. In Midwood, Brooklyn, a sharp gust ripped a tree from its
title: 60-M.P.H. Winds Kill Three and Cause Severe Damage

body: YOU probably know the music and maybe you remember the story: about Peter (portrayed by all the strings in the orchestra) who lassoes the nasty wolf (whose motif is three French horns) who swallowed the duck (oboe) while the cat (clarinet) and bird (flute) took shelter in a tree. title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: MIDWOOD;Prokofiev and Vivaldi, for Children

An acrobat will make a two-legged ladder walk and
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: MIDWOOD;Acrobat Circus: All-Human Fun

body: More than three years have passed since the Democratic Senate primary in which Geraldine A. title: After Retreating From Politics, Ferraro Is Talking About Another Try

body: An article on the Education page yesterday about semifinalists in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search misidentified the school with the third-highest number of semifinalists. It was Midwood High School, in Brooklyn, with nine; Montgomery Blair High School in Silver Spring, Md., had eight.
title: Corrections

body: By the time students make it to the semifinals of the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, they have spent countless hours bent over a marine specimen or staring into a computer screen to study technical data. But many of them have also, at age 14 and 15, persuaded scientists at prestigious laboratories or research universities to let them work with
title: New York Leads List of Westinghouse Science Semifinalists

One of the subs, a 6-foot-3-inch junior forward named Kareem Salley, appeared to have a shot, but he
title: BASKETBALL;This Time, the Hoopla, the Dunks and the Cheers Are for the Schoolboys

body: They came to Brooklyn College from Minsk, Odessa, Tashkent, Baku and Santo Domingo -- every place, it seems, but Brooklyn. When they're not studying computer science, chemistry and psychology, they play chess. And on Dec. 29, their countless hours punching chess clocks and discussing stratagems paid off: the Brooklyn College Chess Team won the Pan
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDWOOD;The Making of a Champion College Chess Team

body: It was another day and another disaster at 110 Livingston Street, the down-at-the-heels Brooklyn headquarters of the nation's largest school system. title: New Player in the Schoolyard;Rudy Crew Settles In and Sets Own Ground Rules
